name: Nuthetes
overview: Nuthetes is a genus of coelurosaurian theropod dinosaur, either a dromaeosaurid or tyrannosauroid, known only from fossil teeth and jaw fragments found in rocks of the middle Berriasian age in the Cherty Freshwater Member of the Lulworth Formation in England and also the Angeac-Charente bonebed in France. If it was a dromaeosaurid, Nuthetes would have been a small predator.

researchContext.evidenceBase: Nuthetes is represented by published fossil material, but completeness and diagnostic overlap can limit high-confidence biological reconstruction.
researchContext.currentLimits: Several ecological and life-history traits remain inferential rather than directly measured for this taxon.
researchContext.nextDataNeeded: Priority evidence includes better-preserved cranial/postcranial overlap, robust stratigraphic control, and specimen-linked morphometrics.
researchContext.revisionOutlook: Interpretation is expected to improve as new finds and reanalyses clarify taxonomy and anatomy.

funFacts: Nuthetes remains an active target for revision as new material is compared across related taxa.
Dino-pedia marks uncertain claims explicitly so this article can be upgraded with specimen-level evidence.
